expected.num_1: last (map (fun x -> x.bleu) (filter (fun x -> (x.layers == 5) `and` (x.max_chunk_size == "k=6")) tableData)) - head (map (fun x -> x.bleu) (filter (fun x -> (x.layers == 1) `and` (x.max_chunk_size == "k=6")) tableData))
expected.num_3: last (map (fun x -> x.speedup) (filter (fun x -> x.layers == 5) tableData))
expected.num_4: head (map (fun x -> x.bleu) (filter (fun x -> (x.max_chunk_size == "k in {1...6}")) tableData)) - head (map (fun x -> x.bleu) (filter (fun x -> (x.layers == 1) `and` (x.max_chunk_size == "k=6")) tableData))
expected.num_6: head (map (fun x -> x.speedup) (filter (fun x -> (x.max_chunk_size == "k in {1...6}")) tableData))

paragraph.value: Table 4 shows that increasing the number of layers from 1 to 5 results in a BLEU increase of only [REPLACE id="num_1" value="0.5"], while the speedup drops from [REPLACE id="num_2" value="3.8] to [REPLACE id="num_3" value="1.4"].  The final row of Table 4 shows that exposing the parse decoder to multiple possible chunking of the same sentence during training allows it to choose a sequence of chunks that has a higher likelihood at test time, improving BLEU by [REPLACE id="num_4" value="1.5"] while decreasing the speedup from [REPLACE id="num_5" value="3.8] to [REPLACE id="num_6" value="3.1"];
